name: NPR
text:
JUST IN: The House has approved wide-ranging legislation aimed at overhauling law enforcement departments following the police killing of George Floyd.

The bill is not expected to move in the GOP-led Senate.
https://t.co/93L0A7Cuq0

name: NPR
text:

Here's how much cases are up compared to 2 weeks ago:

text:
In a newly announced rule, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has signaled she is standing firm on her intention to reroute millions of dollars in coronavirus aid money to K-12 private school students.
https://t.co/60APnN1tcV

name: NPR
text:
Disney is redesigning its popular Splash Mountain ride, which features characters from the controversial film ‚ÄúSong of the South.‚Äù  

The ride will be "re-themed" to focus on 2009 film ‚ÄúThe Princess and the Frog."
https://t.co/vCkkURHqxp

name: NPR
text:
NASA will name its Washington, D.C., headquarters after Mary Jackson, the agency's first African American female engineer and a driving force behind getting U.S. astronauts into space.
https://t.co/hZFD023Z4y

name: NPR
text:
In an interview with NPR, Attorney General Barr defended his claim, without providing any evidence, that foreign countries could potentially counterfeit "millions" of mail ballots in November.

Election officials say that's "preposterous" and "false."
https://t.co/jU1GeNxxqg

name: NPR
text:
Health officials and experts in the San Francisco Bay Area say that while COVID-19 cases are rising, they see little indication ‚Äî at least so far ‚Äî that the Black Lives Matter protests are the cause. (@KQEDscience)
https://t.co/KxYUli6zwr

name: NPR
text:
üê¨ Dolphins learn special foraging tricks from their mothers ‚Äî and now, researchers have found that they can learn from their buddies as well.
https://t.co/AvL02Gm2MN

name: NPR
text:
Jenny Slate and Kristen Bell have agreed to stop voicing characters who are biracial, saying Black actors should be cast instead. 

"In my playing Missy, I was engaging in an act of erasure of Black people," Slate wrote.
https://t.co/cHA9XG7J9Y

name: NPR
text:
Minks are the latest addition to the list of animals that we know can be infected with coronavirus. 

In the case of an outbreak in the Netherlands  ‚Äî the minks are thought to have passed the disease back to humans. https://t.co/Mu4uByhJea

name: NPR
text:
Thanks to their efforts to avoid coronavirus exposure, the U.S. Navy says two American warships that set sail in mid-January broke the modern record for consecutive days at sea for U.S. naval surface vessels.
https://t.co/fHT4n4c8tW

name: NPR
text:
Big companies have borrowed more than a trillion dollars this year ‚Äî  and they are already showing red flags.

Some companies that have borrowed a lot of money are manipulating their numbers to avoid breaking their debt agreements.
https://t.co/uWLu9IflLo

name: NPR
text:
U.S. education has long been full of innovators practicing alternatives to the mainstream. Some of their ideas seem newly relevant, including:

üçé Supporting families to help teach kids
üçé Microschools and homeschool co-ops
üçé Taking school outside https://t.co/jzO6cn7vz4

name: NPR
text:
Illinois is moving into its next phase of reopening on Friday, allowing movie theaters, zoos, museums and fitness centers to reopen with limited capacity. Restaurants will be able to offer in-door dining.
https://t.co/7Twd2oV39r

name: NPR
text:
‚ÄúSearch Party,‚Äù the darkly comic series about four entitled New Yorkers striving to cover up a murder, returns for a third season, now on HBO Max.
https://t.co/PSFS1929QO

name: NPR
text: A smart thermometer company's database of users' temperature readings has become a strong leading indicator of COVID-19 outbreaks across the country. ‚ÄúThe health care system doesn't see mildly symptomatic spread. We do.‚Äù @hereandnow https://t.co/ifADKDCfNk

name: NPR
text: Ottessa Moshfegh's ‚ÄúDeath In Her Hands‚Äù isn't exactly a murder mystery, conventional or otherwise. It‚Äôs more of portrait of a woman gradually losing her mind, using the mystery to hang on.  https://t.co/7dHJZIfR7H

name: NPR
text:
Every December, many people in the Netherlands paint their faces black to portray Dutch character Black Pete.

As the Black Lives Matter movement spreads across the globe, the holiday season in the Netherlands may see a change.
https://t.co/xm8Rnirfkk

name: NPR
text:
In an interview with NPR, Attorney General Barr defended his claim that recent protests against racism and police brutality have been infiltrated by Antifa agitators.

NPR reporting has found no sign of Antifa links so far in cases brought by the DOJ.
https://t.co/jqfEPTPUqh

name: NPR
text:
Georgia Lt. Gov. Geoff Duncan discusses the three major crises gripping his state: rising cases of COVID-19, voting issues during the recent primary, and the killings of two Black men, Ahmaud Arbery and Rayshard Brooks.
https://t.co/SlT0uuE2WI

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. reported 40,401 new COVID-19 cases on Thursday ‚Äî surpassing the previous one-day record set April 24, which saw 36,291 new cases.
https://t.co/WxVT17zc1Y

name: NPR
text:
"My great-grandfather, who walked away from slavery in Virginia, got as far as the District of Columbia ‚Äî got to freedom, but not to equality," says Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton.

She says she dedicates the House bill to make D.C. the 51st state to him. https://t.co/RivmGI4tK9

name: NPR
text:
In a filing with the Supreme Court late last night, the Trump administration reaffirmed its position to eliminate the Affordable Care Act in its entirety.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi called the move "an act of unfathomable cruelty" amid the pandemic.
https://t.co/xc5bQ4Tt90

name: NPR
text: RT @MorningEdition: Nearly a year after Elijah McClain died in police custody, Colorado Gov. Jared Polis has appointed a special prosecutor to reopen the case. https://t.co/9T5hOT4BAl
